questions.question: Question 1: Which of the following is a pure opioid antagonist?
questions.explanation:
Both naloxone and naltrexone are pure opioid antagonists. Nalorphine is an agonist-antagonist. It has antagonistic activity at the mu receptor and additional 
agonistic activity at the kappa receptor. Note: Nalmefene is sometimes classified as a pure antagonist but it has additional kappa receptor 
partial agonist activity.

questions.question: Question 2: Which of the following statements is incorrect about opioid antagonists?

options.a: Naloxone is a short acting drug
options.c: Nalmefene can be used for treatment of opioid overdose
options.d: Nalmefene is shorter acting than naloxone

questions.explanation: Nalmefene is longer-acting (not shorter-acting) than naloxone.

questions.question: Question 3: Which of the following is false about naltrexone?

options.b: Is used in the treatment of alcohol dependence

questions.explanation:
Naltrexone is more potent than naloxone. Naltrexone is a pure opioid antagonist which is orally active. Alcohol craving is reduced by naltrexone. It is also approved for the prevention of relapse in 
opioid addiction treatment.

questions.question:
Question 4: A patient is on chronic opioid therapy for pain management. He would not develop tolerance 
against which of the following actions of opioids?
questions.explanation: Tolerance is developed to all the above actions of opioids except for miosis. Exceptions to opioid tolerance (3C's): • Constricted pupil (miosis) • Constipation • Convulsions

questions.question:
Question 5: An elderly man, who is on chronic morphine therapy for pain relief, visits your clinic with 
complaints of not passing stools for the last 4 days. Which of the following drugs is best 
suited to treat his condition?
questions.explanation:
392 
Sold by @itachibot The given clinical picture points towards opioid-induced constipation. Methylnaltrexone, an 
opioid antagonist with predominant peripheral action is best suited for treating opioid-induced 
constipation. Methylnaltrexone is a peripheral µ receptor antagonist. It was introduced in the treatment of 
opioid-induced constipation refractory to other measures. It is a quaternary ammonium compound and hence cannot cross the blood-brain barrier. It can 
reverse the effects mediated by peripheral opioid receptors and spares CNS effects like analgesia. The peripherally acting opioid antagonists include: • Methylnaltrexone • Naloxegol • Naldemedine • Alvimopan

questions.question: Question 6: Which of the following is not an antagonist at µ receptor?
questions.explanation:
Naltrindole is a new non-peptide drug which has a selective antagonistic activity on the  receptor. 
This drug is still in the trial phase and is not yet in use. Option B: Naloxone is considered a pure opioid receptor antagonist but at high doses, it is found 
to have partial agonistic activity on the - and -opioid receptors. Option C: Nalbuphine is an agonist-antagonist opioid which acts as an antagonist at the  receptor 
and an agonist at the  receptor. Option D: Naltrexone is a -, - and -opioid receptor antagonist.

questions.question:
Question 7: A 27-year-old man presented to the casualty with slurred speech and shallow breathing. On 
examination, you find he has bradycardia, hypotension, and pin-point pupils. Which drug will 
you choose to treat him?
questions.explanation:
The given clinical features are suggestive of opioid overdose. Naloxone is the drug of choice for 
opioid overdose. Opioid overdose symptoms: • Triad of coma, respiratory depression, and pinpoint pupils (miosis) • Hypotension, bradycardia • Shallow breathing • Hypothermia Naloxone is also used for reversing neonatal asphyxia due to opioid usage in labor. Naloxone is a 
pure opioid antagonist which reverses all effects except sedation. Note: Naloxone is contraindicated in infants born to mothers with opiate addiction as it may 
precipitate acute neonatal withdrawal with seizures. 393

Question 8: 389 
Sold by @itachibot A college student who is addicted to intravenous heroin abruptly stopped abusing the drug 
during exams. Which of the following would you not expect as a part of withdrawal?
questions.explanation: Diarrhea (not constipation) is seen in opioid withdrawal. Opioid withdrawal symptoms (mnemonic- O MY WITHDRAWALS): • Mydriasis • Yawning • Weakness • Insomnia, irritability • Tremors, tachycardia • Hypertension, hyperactive • Diarrhea • Rhinorrhoea • Apnoeic attacks • Weight loss • Anxiety • Lacrimation • Sweating

questions.question:
Question 9: An elderly woman who was dependent on morphine for her palliative care recently got 
switched to another opioid medication. A few days later she started developing withdrawal 
symptoms. Which of the following opioids would have been prescribed to her?
questions.explanation:
Pentazocine can precipitate withdrawal symptoms in opioid-dependent patients. It acts as a weak antagonist or partial agonist at mu-opioid receptors which may precipitate 
withdrawal symptoms. Options A, C, and D: Pethidine, morphine, and methadone are pure agonists at mu-receptors and 
do not precipitate withdrawal symptoms.

questions.question:
Question 10: A 33-year-old man with a history of heroin addiction is referred to a rehabilitation center. 
Which of the following would you use as a substitute drug for maintenance therapy?
questions.explanation:
Methadone is used as a substitute drug for the maintenance therapy of opioid (heroin) 
dependence. This is because of its good oral bioavailability and long half-life. Methadone is substituted for opioids during detoxification to avoid withdrawal symptoms. Once 
stabilized, the dose is gradually reduced and the drug is stopped slowly over days. Due to its long half-life and accumulation in tissues, discontinuing the drug still results in low 
concentrations of the drug in plasma resulting in protracted withdrawal symptoms. 394 
Sold by @itachibot Maintainance therapy for opioid dependence: • Long-acting opioid agonist - a safer substitute like methadone is given in a supervised manner to 
prevent withdrawal symptoms • Partial agonist - buprenorphine can also be used • Clonidine, lofexidine - alpha-2 agonists act as sympatholytic and reduce the withdrawal 
symptoms • LAAM(L-Alpha-Acetyl-Methadol) - opioid agonist which reduces craving • Naltrexone - is an opioid antagonist used in maintenance therapy to prevent relapses

questions.question:
Question 11: A physician prescribes naltrexone to a patient undergoing treatment for opioid addiction. 
What is the function of this drug in opioid addiction?
questions.explanation:
Naltrexone is used for the prevention of relapse in opioid addiction. It is given only after initial opioid detoxification. The patient should be opioid-free for 7-10 days 
and have a negative naloxone challenge (no withdrawal after naloxone administration). Naltrexone is a pure opioid antagonist which is more potent than naloxone. It is orally active and 
has a long duration of action which makes it suitable for opioid blockade therapy in post-addicts.

questions.question:
Question 12: Which of the following is incorrect about the use of naltrexone in the treatment of opioid 
addiction?

options.a: Discontinuation of naltrexone does not cause withdrawal symptoms
options.b: It satisfies craving in opioid addicts
options.c: It blocks the effects of opioids if they are used
options.d: It is administered only when the patient has completed detoxification from opioids

questions.explanation:
Naltrexone does not satisfy the craving of opioid addicts. It is an opioid antagonist with a high 
affinity for  opioid receptors. Naltrexone does not suppress craving in opioid addiction but it suppresses craving in chronic 
alcoholics. Opioid agonists such as methadone and buprenorphine suppress craving and withdrawal 
symptoms and are therefore used in the first stage of detoxification in opioid addiction. Option A: Discontinuation of naltrexone ingestion has no negative physical consequences, as 
opposed to discontinuation of agonist maintenance therapies, which results in the emergence of 
opioid withdrawal symptoms. This is a major reason for noncompliance and treatment failure. Option C: It blocks the effects of opioids and prevents the user from experiencing subjective 
symptoms of opioid intoxication such as euphoria on subsequent use. As the user does not 
experience these symptoms, he does not develop a craving for the substance. Thus, naltrexone 
prevents relapse. Option D: It is only administered when the patient has completed a medically supervised 
detoxification from opioids because it can cause immediate withdrawal symptoms.
